fields.description:
As an administrator of the Eucalyptus Management Console I would like a centralized caching service so that my deployed console uses memory efficiently.

Background:
The 4.0 console has in-memory caching configured via Beaker, which leads to inefficient memory usage when the console is deployed with gunicorn workers since each worker had its own memory space.  Using a centralized caching service such as memcached will lead to more efficient utilization of machine resources and will result in a more predictable caching experience.
fields.summary: Centralized cache service for Management Console

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.summary: Ensure console supports SASL for memcached

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

comments.body: We should strongly consider switching our caching library from Beaker to dogpile.cache

For reference: http://techspot.zzzeek.org/2012/04/19/using-beaker-for-caching-why-you-ll-want-to-switch-to-dogpile.cache/
Dogpile.cache is written by the same author as beaker and is evolutionary. It fixes some performance issues with beaker.

I stayed up last night to try to advance the "shared-cache" branch I started last week. The goal was to replace the beaker.cache implementation with dogpile.cache and use mecached as the back end. For reasons to not simply use beaker with mecached, read this: http://techspot.zzzeek.org/2012/04/19/using-beaker-for-caching-why-you-ll-want-to-switch-to-dogpile.cache/

I've installed these 2 additional packages;
https://pypi.python.org/pypi/dogpile.cache/0.5.3
https://pypi.python.org/pypi/python-memcached/1.53
in addition, I installed memcached on on my laptop (and run that in a separate shell using 'memcached -vv')

The usage of dogpile.cache is a little different, but essentially the same. You still define a "creation" method that fetches the data you wish to cache. You use a decorator to specify that the results get cached. Cache keys are generated automatically based on those function arguments, so you can pass values that aren't needed by the method, simply to include them in the cache key.
I ran into trouble with not being able to get the value saved in the cache. I've been connecting to memcached via telnet "telnet localhost 11211" and can issue commands like "stats", "stats items", etc. That can show what's happening with the cache more directly. Also using "-vvv" when starting memcached provides even more verbose output for debugging.\

So, back to the values not saving.. Spent time in pdb and there isn't anything preventing the value being saved from what I can tell. Though after giving up last night, I thought we might be facing a problem with pickling the boto objects. pickling is the encoding scheme used to send objects to the cache over the wire. We've had problems pickling or json-encoding boto objects in the past and I wrote a special encoder to convert them to json for the 3.x console. I think this is where the problem lays. I even found someone online who said "I always convert my objects to dictionaries or json before caching".

In reading, I also found some useful insights from dogpile.cache's author Mike Bayer.
https://bitbucket.org/zzzeek/dogpile.cache/issue/17/is-there-any-way-to-force-a-refresh
One thing that stood out for our consideration was;

"the region is meant to be kind of a homebase for a certain set of config, so it wasn't intended to be per-key or anything like that"

This means we could (should) define a single cache region based on expiration. Expiration can be overridden later, but it is more convenient to configure when setting up the region. Another thing I noticed is that you can define a namespace for each thing  you cache. That means that for (say) images, you could define an images namespace. That gets included in the cache key prior to the argument list passed to the function. In that way, we could separate the different resource caches within the region. An example is:
    @cache_region.cache_on_arguments(namespace="images")
    def _get_images_cached_(self, _owners, _executors, _ec2_region, acct):

Notice that self is there, which doesn't get included in the cache key. Also notice "acct" which is used purely to cache based on account. I can pass "" for acct to have a shared value across accounts (like for 'amazon' and 'aws_marketplace' images)

I think that's it for now. I will play with making the image list serializable before caching to see if that helps. Beyond that, there is more work to more properly configure the regions we need and handle installing memcached as a dependency. Invalidation is a little different here as well (as the discussion in that last link talks about). Once I can get a value saved and retrieved from the cache, I think this will work out fine.

I've been able to get the images list to save in the cache (and pull from the cache). The browser is able to get one list of 300 images in 70 ms vs 3 seconds when the cache is used.
I did that by removing the connection and block device mapping objects from the images. Making the block_device_mapping object serializable will allow that part to be cached as well. When loading a larger image set (aws marketplace), it fails to save in the cache which leads me to think there is some component of at least 1 of those images that isn't serializable, probably product codes.
Good news overall is that we're starting to have success.

Still haven't ironed out the saving, but am able to get a set of images saving reliably in the cache to test invalidation. I created a custom key generator per the recipe at the bottom of http://dogpilecache.readthedocs.org/en/latest/usage.html#invalidating-a-group-of-related-keys
Using that, I'm able to delete specific cache sets and re-write invalidate_image_cache() to specifically delete the "owned by self" and "executable by self" image sets. Invalidating the cache requires passing the specific cache, namespace and set of arguments used in the @cache_on_arguments decorator.

As of now, I am happy with the saving code. I figured out how to clean the data before saving, and how to enable compression so that larger data sets fit in the 1MB limit of memcached. We still may still run into problem with very large image sets since a set of 2585 image records compressed to 650MB, but the failure mode is that the image set is not cached, which doesn't affect data integrity. We *may* have to think about splitting up the image set, or looking for a python memcached library that does that. There are 2 or 3 that dogpile.cache supports.

I tested using the branch on CentOS. I installed memcached 1.4.4-3 which is the latest in the centos-6 repo. I also ran 'python setup.py develop' and got all of the python dependencies installed without any trouble. After starting memcached, I was able to run the console server and saw that caching was working based on response times in the browser.
Great to hear it works on CentOS, thanks [~dkavanagh]!
We'll want to document configuration options [~tvo]. Memcached has some options that might be exploited in production for various topologies.

When memcached isn't running, caching code simply does not store information. That's fine for pure cache usage since data is just fetched from the server instead. For the "file_cache" feature that uses the cache, that will fail.
Need to determine what default memcached limit is and how close we would be with all public aws image sets (that we support) cached.
Concerns raised about complexity of configuring memcached. Need more evaluation.

The default memory for memcached is:
-m <num>      max memory to use for items in megabytes (default: 64 MB)

We cache image lists (amazon, aws marketplace and user images). The size of the first two in aws us-west-1 is (215759+682165=897924). That is slightly different for each region, but those numbers are some of the higher ones. So, multiply 900K * 7 regions and get 6.3MB. Since that's an order of magnitude below the default memory limit, I think we're fine with that for the near future.

UPDATE: I tested memcached configured with 1MB. I found that when the cache fills up, older values are kicked out to keep below the limit. I tested this by telnet-ing into memcached and running "stats" to show memory usage. Here's an example of 2 values I was looking at:
STAT bytes_written 911487
STAT limit_maxbytes 1048576
The bytes_written value would change, but remain in that general range as I added more values. I would do this by switching to an AWS region I haven't viewed before and looking a different image sets. I could then create a keypair and the file was available for download, which means that won't break when the cache is "full". This also means the cache has a pretty decent full fall-back behavior in that it handles it gracefully.

Submitted an issue to dogpile.cache about detecting memcached set failure: https://bitbucket.org/zzzeek/dogpile.cache/issue/64/unable-to-detect-when-memcached-isnt

I coded a patch to dogpile.cache to help with memcached failures. I can now run the application without memecached running at all. We fall-back to using session storage for files.

Based on feedback from the dogpile.cache author, I'm looking at pylibmc which has better error handling

[~rusvika] and I just discussed a suitable set of options for 4.1
- don't store temporary keys/cred files in memcached, use same session based mechanism as in 4.0
- support SASL auth for memcached, but don't ship with that enabled ([~tvo], need to document use of this option)
- set up memcached with localhost connections only ([~tvo], need to document changing this when scaling out console)
Stuck getting travis to execute automated unit tests. They run locally and on their own debug VM.
